questions.text: Which of the following is lined by simple squamous epithelium? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Loop of Henle

 

Explanation: 

                                   

Loop of Henle is lined by simple squamous epithelium. This specialized thin epithelium facilitates passive diffusion and reabsorption of water and electrolytes. The flattened cells with their minimal thickness are perfectly suited for the Loop of Henle's function in the renal tubular system, allowing efficient transport across the epithelial layer.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) - PCT is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with a prominent brush border. These cuboidal cells have numerous microvilli that increase surface area for active reabsorption of filtered substances.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. These cells have fewer microvilli than PCT cells but contain numerous mitochondria to support active transport processes.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - Collecting ducts are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. In some regions, particularly deeper parts, the epithelium may become columnar, but it is never squamous.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Simple squamous epithelium is found in areas requiring rapid transport, diffusion, or filtration such as the Loop of Henle, alveoli of lungs, and endothelium of blood vessels due to its thin, flattened morphology that facilitates these functions.

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bridging veins

 

The image demonstrating a bleed over the arachnoid layer but beneath the dura suggests a subdural hemorrhage. It is most commonly caused by the shearing of cortical bridging veins.

 

A subdural hemorrhage is a type of intracranial hemorrhage, which is bleeding within the skull. It occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater (the tough outermost layer of the meninges) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer of the meninges) surrounding the brain.

 

Subdural hemorrhages are usually caused by trauma to the head, such as falls or motor vehicle accidents, which can tear the veins that bridge the dura and arachnoid layers. The bleeding can create pressure on the brain, leading to neurological symptoms such as headaches, confusion, dizziness, seizures, and in severe cases, coma or death.

 

The symptoms of a subdural hemorrhage can develop immediately or may take hours or even days to appear, depending on the severity of the bleeding. In some cases, a small subdural hemorrhage may resolve on its own without treatment, while larger or more severe bleeds may require surgery to relieve pressure on the brain and stop the bleeding.

 

Factors that can increase the risk of a subdural hemorrhage include advanced age, alcohol or drug abuse, blood-thinning medications, and medical conditions that affect blood clotting or increase the risk of falls. Early recognition and treatment of a subdural hemorrhage can improve outcomes and prevent complications.

 

Dx:- Non-Contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Lenticulostriate artery would lead to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of a subdural hemorrhage is crucial following head trauma, especially in individuals at higher risk such as the elderly, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with a history of alcohol abuse. Immediate medical evaluation is vital to manage the condition effectively and mitigate potential severe outcomes.

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastin fibres

 

Explanation:

 

Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.

 

The ventral portions of the laminae of nearby vertebrae are connected by a network of ligaments called the Ligament flava. They make up a portion of the posterior surface of the spinal canal and primarily consist of elastic tissue. Because it contains a lot of elastin, it can be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm. The ligamentum flava helps with extension back to the anatomical position by helping to prevent laminae separation during flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 collagen: Collagen is the primary structural protein, among the different types of collagen, Type 1 collagen is the most abundant. It's found in many tissues including skin, tendons, internal organs, and the organic part of bones. Its primary function is to provide tensile strength to these tissues. It forms strong fibers and is responsible for the strength of the tissue. However, while present in many areas of the body, Type 1 collagen is not the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Option B. Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in cartilaginous tissues. Its main function is to provide resistance against intermittent pressure, making it ideal for cartilaginous structures like the intervertebral discs, hyaline cartilage, and the vitreous humor of the eye. Given that ligamentum flavum is not a cartilaginous structure, Type 2 collagen is not its predominant component.

 

Option C. Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers are a type of fiber in connective tissue composed of Type 3 collagen. These fibers form a mesh-like framework in various organs such as the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. They provide a supportive framework for these and other organs. While they are present in various parts of the body, they are not the main component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligamentum flavum, which connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae, contains a high concentration of elastin fibers, which allows the ligament to stretch during spine flexion and then return to its original shape when the spine is extended.

 

This characteristic helps maintain the stability and alignment of the vertebral column. Thus, among the given options, elastin fibers are the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peroneus longus

 

The peroneus longus is a muscle of the lateral compartment of the leg. It originates from the head and upper two-thirds of the fibula, and it has a long tendon that wraps behind the lateral malleolus and extends to the medial side of the foot, inserting into the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform. When the peroneus longus contracts, it everts the foot and also plantarflexes the ankle. Therefore, the peroneus longus is not involved in the inversion of the foot.

 

Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.

 

  • Tibialis anterior - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot
  • Tibialis posterior - Plantar flexion and inversion of the foot
  • Extensor hallucis longs - Extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and inversion of the foot (minimal action)

 

Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally.

 

  • Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved.

 

These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and partly at the transverse tarsal joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and inserts into the medial cuneiform and first metatarsal bones of the foot. When this muscle contracts, it dorsiflexes the ankle (pulls the foot upwards, towards the shin) and inverts the foot. Therefore, the tibialis anterior plays a role in foot inversion.

 

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior is located in the deep compartment of the leg. It originates from the posterior surfaces of the tibia and fibula and inserts into various bones in the foot, including the navicular, cuneiforms, and metatarsals. When the tibialis posterior contracts, it plantarflexes the ankle (points the foot downward) and also inverts the foot. Like the tibialis anterior, the tibialis posterior is involved in foot inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus is another muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the anterior surface of the fibula and the interosseous membrane and inserts into the distal phalanx of the big toe. Its primary action is to dorsiflex the big toe. While it plays a role in dorsiflexion of the ankle, its contribution to inversion or eversion is minimal compared to the other muscles listed. However, it can assist in inversion to a minor extent when combined with other inverters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar flexion.

 

The transverse tarsal joint and the talocalcaneal and talocalcaneonavicular joints also play a role in inversion and eversion movements

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Attached with transverse process of C7

questions.text: Which among the following statement is incorrect regarding Sibson’s fascia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

 

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

 

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

 

Clinical significance

 

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung (Correct): Sibson's fascia covers the apical (uppermost) part of the lung and helps separate the cervical pleura from the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Attached with transverse process of C7 (Correct): Sibson's fascia is posteriorly attached with the tip of the transverse process of C7.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia (Correct): Blood vessels, including the subclavian vessels, pass above Sibson's fascia as they enter and exit the thoracic cavity. This fascia serves as a landmark for the placement of central venous catheters, as it delineates the boundary between the cervical and thoracic regions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sibson's fascia is not directly attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib. Instead, it is associated with the cervical pleura and extends superiorly to attach to the transverse process of the 7th cervical (C7) vertebra. It forms the outer boundary of the cervicothoracic (suprapleural) space.

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X). These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions. While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta). This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

 

Option B. Azygous Vein: It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava. This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

 

Option C. Thoracic Duct: It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body. It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the main action of the muscle marked below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Elevation

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis and its main action is elevation of the mandible.

 

Other actions are:

 

  • ﻿﻿It helps in the side-to-side grinding movements of the mandible.
  • ﻿﻿The posterior fibres which are horizontal, help in the retraction of the mandible.

 

The muscles of mastication are a group of four muscles that are responsible for the movements of the jaw during chewing (mastication). These muscles include:

 

Together, these muscles work to elevate and depress the mandible, move it side to side, and protrude it forward. They are important for chewing, speaking, and swallowing. Dysfunction of these muscles can result in temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders and other oral health problems.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: This action is not associated with the temporalis muscle. Depression of the mandible, which involves opening the jaw, is primarily accomplished by the digastric muscle and, to some extent, by the lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

Option C. Protrusion: Protrusion refers to pushing the jaw forward. This action is chiefly performed by the lateral pterygoid muscle, not the temporalis.

 

Option D. Retraction: While the posterior fibers of the temporalis muscle do assist in retraction of the mandible, pulling it backward, it is not the primary action of the entire muscle. The main retractor of the jaw is the posterior part of the temporalis muscle alongside the digastric muscle (posterior belly).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. L5

 

Explanation:

 

The green line marked on the torso corresponds to the L5 vertebral level. This line is also known as the intertubercular plane or Tuffier's line, which is anatomically aligned with the upper border of the L5 vertebra. The intertubercular plane is significant in clinical settings as it passes through the highest points of the iliac crests, located at the L4-L5 intervertebral disc space. This reference point is crucial for procedures such as spinal anesthesia and lumbar punctures, where accurate identification of vertebral levels is essential.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • It serves as a reference point for various medical procedures, particularly those involving the lumbar spine, spinal anesthesia, and the placement of lumbar punctures (spinal taps).
  • When performing a lumbar puncture, healthcare providers often use the intertubercular plane as a landmark to identify the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the subarachnoid space.
    • Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century.
    • Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T12: Incorrect as it corresponds to the lower end of the thoracic spine.

 

Option C. L1: Incorrect and typically aligns with the lower border of the first lumbar vertebra.

 

Option D. L3: Incorrect as it corresponds to the subcostal plane, not the intertubercular plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abdominal Planes & Quadrants –

 

 

#2 Horizontal Plane -

  • Subcostal Plane (L3)
  • Trans tubercular Plane (L5- upper border)

#2 Vertical Planes

Midclavicular Line / Plane (from midpoint of clavicle till midinguinal point)

  • Trans-pyloric Plane of Addison - Lower border of L1

Supracristal Plane - L4

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by which dermatome ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

questions.text: Which structure is advised to occlude in ligation of splenic artery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. D

 

Explanation:

 

Structure D will be occluded in order to ligate the splenic artery.

 

Peritoneal ligaments

 

  1. Gastrosplenic ligaments
  2. Splenorenal ligaments / Lienorenal ligaments (Extends from spleen to Left kidney)

 

Contents

 

  1. TAIL of PANCREAS
  2. SPLENIC VESSELS

 

 

 

In the ligation of the splenic artery, the primary objective is to interrupt the blood supply to the spleen. This procedure may be performed for various medical reasons, such as treating splenic artery aneurysms or managing traumatic injuries to the spleen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Portal Vein: The portal vein is a major blood vessel that carries nutrient-rich, oxygen-poor blood from the digestive organs (stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and spleen) to the liver. It is not advisable to occlude the portal vein during ligation of the splenic artery because doing so would disrupt blood flow to the liver, potentially leading to severe liver dysfunction and complications.

 

Option B. Hepatogastric Ligament: The hepatogastric ligament is a connective tissue structure that attaches the liver to the stomach. It does not play a significant role in the blood supply to the spleen, so occluding it would not achieve the intended goal of interrupting blood flow to the spleen.

 

Option C. Gastrosplenic Ligament: The gastrosplenic ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. Although it is in close proximity to the spleen, occluding this ligament alone would not effectively disrupt the blood supply to the spleen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament, also known as the splenorenal ligament, is the structure that connects the spleen to the kidney. It contains the splenic artery, which is the primary vessel supplying blood to the spleen. During ligation of the splenic artery, the lienorenal ligament is typically addressed, and the splenic artery within this ligament is occluded, effectively cutting off the blood supply to the spleen.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesser wing of sphenoid

 

The pterion is a point on the side of the skull where several bones meet, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The lesser wing of the sphenoid is one of the bones that contributes to the formation of the pterion. It's an important landmark because it's located just behind the pterion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post clivus: The clivus is a bony ridge on the occipital bone, and it is located at the base of the skull. The "post clivus" isn't a commonly used term in anatomy, and it's not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option C. Sella turcica: The sella turcica is a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone where the pituitary gland is located. It is situated more toward the center of the skull, behind the eyes and nasal cavity, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option D. Carotid canal: The carotid canal is a passage in the temporal bone that houses the internal carotid artery. It is located deeper within the skull, closer to the middle ear, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

1. Frontal bone

2. Squamous part of the temporal bone

3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

4. Parietal bone

questions.text: All of the following are boundaries of the quadrangular space, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Supraspinatus

 

Explanation:

 

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical landmark in the scapular region where the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels pass. The correct boundaries of this space include teres minor superiorly (forming the superior boundary), teres major inferiorly (forming the inferior boundary), long head of triceps medially (forming the medial boundary), and the surgical neck of humerus laterally. Supraspinatus is not a boundary of this space - it lies in the supraspinous fossa of the scapula, superior to the region of the quadrangular space.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Teres minor: This is actually a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its superior border. It is one of the rotator cuff muscles originating from the lateral border of the scapula.
  • Option C. Teres major: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its inferior border. It originates from the dorsal surface of the inferior angle of the scapula.
  • Option D. Long head of triceps: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its medial border. It originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadrangular space is bounded by teres minor superiorly, teres major inferiorly, long head of triceps medially, and the surgical neck of humerus laterally - with the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels as its contents.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (Twisted PYQ)

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Inferior alveolar nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it enters the mandibular foramen.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Mental nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges through mental foramen.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,3

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1: True. The auriculotemporal nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve and emerges posterior to the temporomandibular joint to supply sensory innervation to the temporal region.

 

Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve is indeed a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve and characteristically arcs around the submandibular duct in its course.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. The inferior alveolar nerve is a branch from the posterior division, not the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. The mental nerve is a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (posterior division), not from the anterior division.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The divisions and branches of the mandibular nerve is crucial for dental procedures and facial surgeries. The posterior division gives rise to the auriculotemporal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, while the anterior division provides motor innervation and gives rise to the buccal nerve.

questions.text: A person had a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist in dorsiflexion and radial deviation. On examination, there is tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox with pain on axial loading of the thumb. Which complication is most likely to develop if this injury is missed? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Avascular necrosis of proximal pole

 

Explanation: 

 

A fall on an outstretched hand commonly results in scaphoid fracture. The unique blood supply of the scaphoid (retrograde from distal to proximal) makes it particularly susceptible to avascular necrosis of the proximal pole when fractured. Key points:

  1. The proximal pole receives its blood supply through vessels entering distally
  2. Any fracture can disrupt this tenuous blood supply
  3. 30% of scaphoid fractures progress to AVN if untreated
  4. Risk is highest with proximal pole fractures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kienbock's disease: Incorrect. This refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate, not a complication of scaphoid fractures.

 

Option C. Median nerve compression: Incorrect. While carpal bone injuries can cause swelling and nerve compression, it's not a typical complication of untreated scaphoid fractures.

 

Option D. Carpal tunnel syndrome: Incorrect. Although wrist trauma can lead to carpal tunnel syndrome, it's not the characteristic complication of untreated scaphoid fractures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The retrograde blood supply of the scaphoid makes the proximal pole particularly vulnerable to avascular necrosis following fracture, especially if diagnosis and treatment are delayed.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lienorenal ligament

 

The structure marked in the image is identified as the lienorenal ligament. The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal ligament that connects the spleen to the left kidney. It is crucial because it contains important structures such as the splenic artery and vein.

 

In the provided image, you can see the vertebra centrally located, with the kidneys visible on each side. The spleen, which lies adjacent to the stomach, is connected to the kidney by the lienorenal ligament. The splenic artery, a branch of the celiac trunk, passes through this ligament.

 

During surgical procedures, especially when ligating the splenic artery, knowledge of this ligament's anatomy is essential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. It contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery. However, in the provided image, the marked structure does not represent this ligament.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum extending from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum. It contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct). The marked structure in the image is not the lesser omentum.

 

Option D. Greater omentum: This is a large apron-like fold of visceral peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach. It covers the intestines but is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal structure connecting the spleen to the kidney and contains the splenic artery. This ligament is essential for surgeons to identify, especially during procedures involving the spleen or splenic artery.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with difficulty chewing and restricted jaw movement. Upon examination, a muscle originating from the 1st pharyngeal arch is found to be affected. Which of the following muscles is least likely to originate from the 1st pharyngeal arch? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Levator veli palatini

 

Explanation:


The 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to muscles of mastication (e.g., medial and lateral pterygoids, masseter, temporalis) and other derivatives such as the tensor veli palatini and tensor tympani. The levator veli palatini, however, is derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch, not the 1st pharyngeal arch. This muscle plays a role in elevating the soft palate, especially during swallowing and speaking.

 

Other options:


Option A) Medial pterygoid: This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is responsible for assisting in mastication by closing the jaw.

 

Option C) Lateral pterygoid: This muscle also originates from the 1st pharyngeal arch and helps in opening the jaw and side-to-side movements.

 

Option D) Tensor veli palatini: The tensor veli palatini is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is involved in tensing the soft palate.

 

Educational Objective:


The levator veli palatini is derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch, while the muscles of mastication and tensor veli palatini are derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternothyroid

 

  • Sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles attach to the thyroid cartilage and can help prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.
  • The apex of thyroid gland is directed laterally to the oblique line of thryroid catilage where it is limited above by the attachment of sternothyroid muscle.
  • The sternohyoid muscle, which arises from the posterior surface of the manubrium and the medial end of the clavicle, also inserts onto the thyroid cartilage and can help anchor the gland in place.
  • Together, the attachment of these muscles to the thyroid cartilage can help prevent the gland from pushing upward and causing compression of adjacent structures in the neck.

 

 

  • The thyroid gland is surrounded by the pretracheal fascia, which is connected to the larynx and enables the thyroid to move during swallowing.
  • The thyrohyoid membrane, a fibrous ligament, attaches to the top of the thyroid cartilage and the hyoid bone, facilitating the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.
  • The ligament of Berry, also known as the suspensory ligament, extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid gland, preventing it from descending into the mediastinum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland, trachea, and associated structures. It anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring that the gland moves up and down with swallowing. However, it does not prevent the upward extension of a thyroid swelling specifically through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: It is a broad, fibrous sheet that connects the thyroid cartilage (of the larynx) to the hyoid bone. It contains the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. While it's a strong structure, its primary role is not to prevent the upward extension of thyroid swellings.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: It is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the thyroid gland's posterior aspect to the cricoid cartilage and the first two tracheal rings. This ligament is a key anatomical structure that serves to limit the superior (upward) movement of the thyroid gland. When performing thyroid surgeries, the ligament of Berry is a crucial landmark as it is located near the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sternothyroid muscle originates from the posterior surface of the manubrium of the sternum and inserts into the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. It functions to depress the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1, 2

 

The Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are components of the pelvic diaphragm, commonly referred to as the levator ani.

 

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum. It is formed by the large levator ani and small coccygeus muscles of two sides and their covering fasciae.

 

 

1. Iliococcygeus: The iliococcygeus is one of the muscles that form the pelvic diaphragm. It is part of the levator ani muscle group. The levator ani consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus muscle extends from the ischial spine (a bony projection in the pelvis) to the coccyx (the tailbone) and contributes to the support of the pelvic floor.
 

2. Pubococcygeus: The pubococcygeus muscle is another component of the levator ani muscle group and is a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It extends from the pubic bone to the coccyx and helps maintain pelvic organ support and control.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Obturator Internus: The obturator internus is not considered a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It is a separate muscle located in the pelvic region, and its primary function is to laterally rotate the thigh. While it is near the pelvic diaphragm, it does not contribute to its formation.
 

4. Deep Transverse Perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscles are not typically considered part of the pelvic diaphragm. These muscles are located in the perineum (the area between the anus and the genitalia) and play a role in stabilizing the perineal body and supporting the pelvic organs. They are important for urinary and fecal continence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

questions.text: Common carotid artery pulse is taken at which level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricoid cartilage

 

Explanation:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The "magic of C6" is an important anatomical landmark.

 

At the C6 level, there is the cricopharyngeal junction, the cricoid cartilage, and the pulsation of the common carotid artery can be felt.

 

The common carotid artery lies just anterior to the carotid tubercle (also known as the Chassaignac tubercle), which is the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra. An artery is palpable when it lies close to a firm bony structure, and in this case, the common carotid artery is palpable due to its proximity to the carotid tubercle at the C6 level.

 

HNF Cadaveric section

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal prominence: The laryngeal prominence, also known as the Adam's apple, is located at a higher level than the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option C. Suprasternal notch: The suprasternal notch is located inferior to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct level for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option D. Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is located superior and lateral to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The carotid tubercle of the C6 vertebra serves as a bony landmark for the pulsation of the common carotid artery.

questions.text: Which embryological structure forms the central tendon of the diaphragm? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septum transversum

 

Explanation:

 

The diaphragm is a dome-shaped musculotendinous structure with distinct embryological origins for its different components:

  1. Development of Central Tendon: 
    • Septum Transversum: Forms the central tendinous part of the diaphragm
    • Develops as a mesodermal plate between the thoracic and abdominal cavities
    • Acts as the primary scaffold for diaphragm development
  2. Other Components and Their Origins:
    • Crura: Derived from dorsal mesentery of esophagus
    • Posterolateral portions: Formed by pleuroperitoneal membranes
    • Peripheral muscular portions: Contributed by body wall musculature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleuroperitoneal membrane: Incorrect. These membranes form the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm, not the central tendon.

 

Option B. Crura: Incorrect. The crura develop from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus and form the muscular pillars around the esophageal hiatus.

 

Option D. Body wall musculature: Incorrect. This contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm but not the central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septum transversum forms the central tendon while other structures contribute to different parts of the mature diaphragm.

questions.text: Which artery is used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis and is present behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendon calcaneus? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used in arteriovenous (AV) shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis access. This artery runs in the posterior compartment of the leg and is palpable behind the medial malleolus, approximately 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon calcaneus (Achilles tendon). It is a reliable location for vascular access because of its relatively superficial position and ease of palpation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery is located in the lateral compartment of the leg and does not course near the medial malleolus, making it unsuitable for the AV shunting procedure described in the question.

 

Option B. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and passes between the medial and lateral malleoli, where it is palpable in front of the ankle joint. It is not positioned behind the medial malleolus, hence it is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is palpable on the dorsum of the foot near the navicular bone or intermediate cuneiform, far from the medial malleolus and tendon calcaneus. Therefore, it is not used for AV shunting as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery is the artery located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein in procedures like hemodialysis access due to its superficial location and ease of access.

questions.text: What represents the marked area in the given histology of lymph nodes? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mantle zone

 

The area marked in the above image is the mantle zone of a lymph node.

 

The mantle zone is produced as surrounding cells are marginalized by the rapidly growing germinal centre. It is populated by mainly quiescent B cells with condensed heterochromatic nuclei and little cytoplasm (hence the deeply basophilic staining of this region in routine preparations), a few helper T cells, Follicular Dendritic cells and macrophage

 

Lymph node has a primary follicle composed of small, quiescent lymphocytes, and a secondary follicle with a germinal centre composed mainly of antigen-stimulated B cells.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In peripheral lymph nodes, the marginal zone is often inappropriate because they are mixed with the mantle zone cells. And often not well developed in lymph nodes.

 

Option B. The paracortex lies between the cortical follicles and the medulla and is populated mainly by T cells, which are not organized into follicles

 

Option C. Germinal Center located within secondary follicles and is primarily composed of rapidly dividing antigen-stimulated B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mantle zone in lymph nodes is a critical area populated by B cells surrounding the germinal centers, playing a key role in the adaptive immune response by providing a site for B cell quiescence and interaction with helper T cells and antigen-presenting cells.

questions.text: Identify the structure passing through the foramen marked 2? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abducens nerve

 

The foramen marked as 2 in the given image is the superior orbital fissure and the abducens nerve passes through it.

 

Superior ophthalmic fissure is divided into 3 parts by annulus of zinn, parts of fissure and structures passing via each part are listed below:

  1. Superior -lateral part - Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve, trochlear nerve, superior opthalmic vein, lacrimal artery, meningeal branch of lacrimal artery. (Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve and trochlear nerve are the branches of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.
  2. Middle/ Intermediate part - Nasocillary nerve (branch of ophthalmic division of trigeminal), occulomotor nerve (CN 3), abducens nerve (CN - 6) 
  3. Infero - medial part - Inferior opthalmic vein.


Note - Opthalmic vein passes via superior orbital fissure and not artery. Opthalmic artery passes via optic canal.
 

Brief summary about important structures passing via superior ophthalmic fissure is given below
 

Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is essential for eye abduction (outward movement). Damage to the abducens nerve can result in difficulty moving the affected eye outward, leading to diplopia (double vision) when looking toward the affected side.

 

Ophthalmic Division of Trigeminal Nerve (Cranial Nerve V1): The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the upper face, including the forehead, scalp, and anterior part of the scalp. It also provides sensory innervation to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other structures within the orbit.

 

Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for rotating the eye downward and laterally. Damage to the trochlear nerve can lead to difficulty moving the affected eye downward and inward, causing vertical diplopia.

 

Superior ophthalmic vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal Accessory Nerve: This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. It primarily traverses the jugular foramen and is involved in motor functions, particularly in controlling the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option C. Ophthalmic Artery: Although the ophthalmic artery passes through the orbit, it is not transmitted through the foramen marked 2 but accompanies the optic nerve through the optic canal.

 

Option D. Middle Meningeal Artery: The middle meningeal artery enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: A newborn presents with an anterior abdominal wall defect with intestinal loops protruding through a defect lateral to an intact umbilical cord. The exposed contents have no covering membrane. What is the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastroschisis

 

Explanation: 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by herniation of abdominal contents (typically intestines) through a full-thickness defect in the anterior abdominal wall. Key features include:

  1. Location: Defect occurs lateral (usually right side) to an intact umbilical cord
  2. No covering membrane over the herniated contents
  3. Typically smaller defect (2-4 cm) compared to other anterior abdominal wall defects
  4. Associated with young maternal age and environmental factors

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical hernia: Incorrect. Features protrusion through umbilical ring with intact skin coverage.

 

Option C. Bladder exstrophy: Incorrect. Presents with exposed bladder mucosa in lower abdomen with associated genitourinary abnormalities like bifid genitalia and wide pubic symphysis.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: Incorrect. Unlike gastroschisis, omphalocele has a protective membrane covering the herniated contents and occurs centrally at umbilical ring.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gastroschisis is characterized by evisceration of abdominal contents through a paraumbilical defect without a covering membrane, distinguishing it from other anterior abdominal wall defects.

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.

 

Option B. Lentiform Nucleus: Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.

 

Option D. Red Nucleus: Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus. The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The internal capsule is primarily composed of projection fibers that connect the cortex to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. The internal capsule can be divided into three parts: anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. Lesions in these areas can result in different neurological deficits.

 

  • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes. Fronto pontine fibers also pass via anterior limb.
  • The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis. Fronto pontine and cortico nuclear fibers pass via genu.
  • The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits Fronto pontine, cortico spinal fir trunk, upper as well as lower limbs via posterior limb..

 

The retrolenticular part of the internal capsule carries fibers primarily from the optic radiation, which is a bundle of axons that originate from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in this area can result in visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, superior or inferior quadrantanopia. (Parieto pontine and occipito pontine fibers also pass via retrolentiform) Charcots artery supplies the genu and posterior limb. Hence statement 1, 2 and 4 correct.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 4: Internal capsule has projection fibers - The internal capsule contains a large collection of projection fibers that include both ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord, conveying sensory information to the cortex and motor commands away from the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule, a key white matter structure in the brain, contains Charcot's artery-supplied posterior limb, optic radiation in the retrolenticular part, and is primarily composed of projection fibers linking the cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord. Misinformation about the anterior limb's contents highlights the complexity and specificity of its neural pathways.

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C-Hypothalamus

 

The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus. The structure marked as C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus Callosum: It's a large white matter structure found deep within the brain, lying superiorly to the thalamus and under the cortex. It connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

 

  • The primary purpose of the corpus callosum is to integrate motor, sensory, and cognitive performances between the cerebral cortex on one side of the brain to the same region on the other side. Essentially, it allows for communication between the two hemispheres of the brain.

 

Option C. Pituitary Gland: It is a pea-sized structure that's located at the base of the brain, right below the hypothalamus.

 

  • Often referred to as the "master gland," the pituitary gland secretes hormones that control several other endocrine glands. It has an anterior and posterior portion, each releasing specific hormones. These hormones regulate various physiological processes, including growth, reproductive cycles, and stress response.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Located at the ventral part of the brain, below the occipital lobes and posterior to the brainstem.

 

  • The cerebellum is primarily responsible for coordination and fine-tuning of motor movements. It also plays roles in posture and balance, and there is increasing evidence that it's involved in cognitive functions and emotion regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothalamus is situated at the base of the brain, just below the thalamus and right above the pituitary gland. This plays a crucial role in many important functions, including releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite, managing of sexual behavior, and responding to the feeling of being full (eating).

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

 

Explanation:

 

The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.

 

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  •  Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supports pelvic viscera: This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.

 

Option B. Converge downwards and medially: This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.

 

Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

choices.text: Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus
Superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus
Medial rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, superior rectus
Medial rectus, superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus

questions.text: What is the arrangement from near to far of the recti muscles attached towards the limbus? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cross-sectional view of the eye with the extraocular muscles labeled along with their distances of attachment from the limbus (sclerocorneal junction). The order of the recti muscles from closest to farthest attachment to the limbus is:

 

  • Medial rectus (5.5 mm)
  • Inferior rectus (6.5 mm)
  • Lateral rectus (6.9 mm)
  • Superior rectus (7.7 mm)

 

 

Remember :

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C and D are incorrect because they do not list the recti muscles in the correct order from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of the recti muscles from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus (sclerocorneal junction) is: medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, and superior rectus.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectoralis major

 

  • Pectoralis major is mainly involved in flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm (at the shoulder joint) and is not involved in the abduction of the arm.
  • Glenohumeral abduction is about 120° or more. The glenohumeral arthrodesis restricts the abduction at about 45°. Further abduction occurs at the sterno- and acromioclavicular articulations, and contralateral vertebral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus Anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. This muscle helps in the upward rotation of the scapula, allowing the arm to be raised overhead.

 

Option B. Deltoid: The deltoid muscle is a key muscle for overhead abduction of the arm. It has three distinct portions (anterior, middle, and posterior) that cover the shoulder joint. The middle portion of the deltoid is particularly responsible for abduction of the arm, lifting it away from the body.

 

Option C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle also plays a role in the overhead abduction of the arm. The upper fibers of the trapezius assist in elevating the shoulder girdle, contributing to arm abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRINCIPLE MUSCLES ACTING ON SHOULDERS

questions.text: Which segment of the vertebrae is involved in a patient presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and the leg after lifting heavy weight? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S1


The S1 nerve root is commonly involved when a patient presents with pain radiating to the back of the thigh and the leg, especially after activities such as lifting heavy weights. S1 supplies the lateral part of the sole, the small toe, and the lateral aspect of the foot, which aligns with the typical presentation of pain distribution in such cases. The S1 dermatome covers the area from the back of the thigh down to the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S2: While S2 is also located in the lower limb region, it primarily affects the posterior aspect of the thigh and the gluteal region rather than extending into the leg and foot. The symptoms described in the question align more closely with S1 involvement.

 

Option C. L5: The L5 nerve root affects the lateral thigh, anterior shin, and top of the foot, including the big toe. Pain in this dermatome does not typically extend to the back of the thigh and leg as described.

 

Option D. L4: The L4 nerve root typically affects the anterior thigh and the medial aspect of the shin. It does not extend to the back of the thigh or the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:


The S1 nerve root is involved in pain radiating to the back of the thigh and leg, especially affecting the lateral part of the foot and the small toe, common in cases of heavy lifting or nerve compression.

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the muscle responsible for the opening of the mouth? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b

 

In the above image the structure marked ‘b’ represents the lateral pterygoid muscle which is responsible for opening the mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a-Temporalis: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and retraction of mandible.

 

Option C. c – Medial pterygoid: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and ‘side-to-side’ movements of the mandible.

 

Option D. d –Buccinator: This muscle is responsible for compresses cheek against molar teeth
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: A tumor arising from the uncinate process of the pancreas is most likely to compress which of the following vessels? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

 

A tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Superior mesenteric artery originates from the anterior surface of the aorta just below the celiac trunk. It supplies blood to the midgut structures, including parts of the small intestine and the proximal large intestine.

 

Anatomically, the uncinate process of the pancreas lies posterior to the SMA, and its proximity means that tumors arising from the uncinate process can compress or invade the SMA.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Portal vein: It is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. It conveys blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. While tumors of the pancreas can involve the portal vein, especially those in the head and neck region, the uncinate process's direct relationship is more with the Superior mesenteric artery than with the portal vein.

 

Option C. Common hepatic artery: The common hepatic artery typically arises from the celiac trunk and bifurcates into the proper hepatic artery (supplying the liver) and the gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the head of the pancreas. While it's possible for a pancreatic tumor to involve this artery, especially if the tumor is extensive, the uncinate process's primary vascular relationship remains the Superior mesenteric artery.

 

Option D. Inferior mesenteric artery: It is the third major branch of the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the hindgut structures, including the distal part of the large intestine. It is anatomically distant from the uncinate process of the pancreas, so it's less likely to be directly affected by a tumor in this location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small extension of the pancreas that hooks around the superior mesenteric artery and vein. Its anatomical relations include:

 

Superiorly:

 

  • Neck of the pancreas

 

Inferiorly:

 

  • Superior mesenteric vein
  • Superior mesenteric artery

 

Anteriorly:

 

  • Third part of the duodenum
  • Root of the small bowel mesentery

 

Posteriorly:

 

  • Inferior vena cava
  • Aorta
  • Left renal vein
  • Left psoas muscle
  • Transverse mesocolon

 

Medially:

 

  • Pancreatic duct
  • Common bile duct

 

Laterally:

 

  • Right renal vessels
  • Right psoas muscle

 

The uncinate process is an important landmark for the surgeon during pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) as it is often involved in the dissection of the superior mesenteric vein and artery.Top of Form

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close during normal skull development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior

 

The anterior fontanelle (Bregma) is the largest and most prominent fontanelle on a baby's skull.

 

The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

 

These openings in the skull allow for flexibility during childbirth and rapid brain growth during infancy. Fontanelles gradually close as the bones of the skull grow and fuse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Fontanelle (Lambda):

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the occipital and parietal bones of the skull. Unlike the anterior fontanelle, the posterior fontanelle is smaller and less noticeable.
  • The posterior fontanelle usually closes within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Occipital Fontanelle (Sphenoidal):

 

  • The term "occipital fontanelle" is less commonly used, and it may refer to a small soft spot located at the back of the head, near the occipital bone. This area is generally less significant than the anterior and posterior fontanelles and closes early in infancy.

 

Option D. Mastoid Fontanelle:

 

  • The term "mastoid fontanelle" is not commonly used in the context of fontanelles on a baby's skull.
  • The mastoid region of the skull is a bony area located behind the ear, and it does not typically have a soft spot or fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed red arrow inhibit?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. The cells marked with the arrow are Purkinje cells and they inhibit deep nuclei of the cerebellum.

 

Within the white matter, there are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

 

Detailed Overview of Cerebellar Architecture:

 

1. Three Layers of the Cerebellar Cortex:

 

  • Molecular Layer: This is the outermost layer and contains stellate and basket cells. The dendrites of Purkinje cells also extend into this layer. The axons of granule cells, called parallel fibers, run horizontally in this layer.
  • Purkinje Cell Layer: This layer contains the large, flask-shaped Purkinje cells, which are the principal neurons of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells have a single axon that travels to the deep cerebellar nuclei and extensive dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer. They are inhibitory neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granule Cell Layer: The innermost layer contains numerous small granule cells, along with Golgi cells. Granule cells are excitatory neurons that use glutamate as their neurotransmitter. Their axons ascend into the molecular layer where they bifurcate and run as parallel fibers, synapsing with Purkinje cell dendrites.

 

2. White Matter: Beneath the cerebellar cortex is the cerebellar white matter, which consists of myelinated axons. These axons form the afferent and efferent connections of the cerebellum.

 

3. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei: Within the white matter are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

4. Afferent and Efferent Fibers: The cerebellum receives input (afferent fibers) mainly from the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebral cortex and sends output (efferent fibers) to the deep cerebellar nuclei and then out to various parts of the brain, primarily the vestibular nuclei and the thalamus.

 

5. Bergmann Glia: These are specialized astrocytes found in the cerebellum. They have long processes that extend through the Purkinje cell layer into the molecular layer, providing support for neurons and playing a role in neurotransmission.

 

6. Foliation: Grossly, the cerebellum exhibits a series of folia (folds) which are a result of the convolution of the cerebellar cortex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vestibular nuclei and Option C: Basal ganglia are not directly influenced by Purkinje cells.

 

Option B: Anterior horn of spinal is involved in motor neuron activity, unrelated to Purkinje cell output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a vital inhibitory role on the deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for coordinating and refining motor movements and cognitive processing related to movement.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.
