  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medial margin of sartorius

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral triangle is a triangular muscular depression located in the upper part of the thigh. Its boundaries are formed by the inguinal ligament (base), the medial margin of the sartorius muscle (lateral boundary), and the medial border of the adductor longus muscle (medial boundary). The apex of the triangle is formed by the intersection of the sartorius and adductor longus muscles.

 

The sartorius muscle, the longest muscle in the body, originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle with its medial margin. The adductor longus muscle, originating from the pubic tubercle area, forms the medial boundary of the triangle.

 

The floor of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus, pectineus, psoas major tendon, and iliacus muscle (Mnemonic "APPI"). The roof of the triangle is formed by the skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option B. Medial margin of adductor longus: Incorrect. The medial margin of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary of the femoral triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option C. Lateral margin of sartorius: Incorrect. The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, but it is the medial margin of the sartorius that specifically forms this boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial margin of the sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle, while the medial border of the adductor longus muscle forms the medial boundary.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the ER following a suspected stroke. The patient is unable to speak fluently, though he understands the given instructions. Which category of aphasia is most likely present in the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Broca's aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient in the question exhibits symptoms consistent with Broca's aphasia, also known as motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, the patient has difficulty with speech production and articulation but maintains relatively intact language comprehension. This is evident from the fact that the patient understands the given instructions but is unable to speak fluently.

 

Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), is responsible for speech production and articulation. Damage to this area, often caused by a stroke, results in Broca's aphasia. Patients with Broca's aphasia struggle with fluent speech but can typically understand language, as the Wernicke's area remains unaffected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's aphasia : This is a form of sensory aphasia where patients have difficulty understanding language but can produce fluent, albeit meaningless, speech. Wernicke’s area is located at the Posterior part of area no 22. This is associated with hearing loss.

 

Option C. Conduction aphasia : In this type of aphasia, the patient can understand and produce language, but there is a disconnect between the Wernicke's area and the Broca's area (Brodmann areas 39 and 40). This results in difficulty repeating words or phrases, which is not mentioned in the patient's case.

 

Option D. Global aphasia : This is a severe form of aphasia involving both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, leading to impairments in both language production and comprehension. The patient in the question does not exhibit signs of impaired comprehension, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's aphasia, or motor aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in speech production and articulation while language comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by damage to Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) in the frontal lobe, often due to a stroke.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

 

The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which is an opening located just below the mandibular angle.

 

  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve:

 

  • It is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The lingual nerve provides general sensory innervation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It is closely associated with the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the lingual nerve itself doesn't carry taste sensation; it just provides a pathway for the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve:

 

  • The mandibular nerve is the third division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which is the main sensory nerve of the face.
  • It has both sensory and motor components.
  • The sensory branches of the mandibular nerve include the buccal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, which innervate areas such as the lower teeth, gingiva, skin of the cheek, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Its motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication (chewing) and other muscles like the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani nerve:

 

  • It's a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It also carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, which play a role in salivation.
  • While it is not a branch of the mandibular nerve, it is closely associated with the lingual nerve (a branch of V3) in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior alveolar nerve is another major branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) which provides sensory innervation to the lower teeth (mandibular teeth) and the surrounding gingiva. Before it enters the mandibular canal in the jaw, it gives off a branch called the mental nerve, which exits the jaw through the mental foramen to supply sensation to the lower lip and chin. The inferior alveolar nerve also carries motor fibers to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation

 

  • The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates presynaptic secretory vesicles.
  • The structure marked with the arrowhead is postsynaptic density.
  • The secretory vesicles are synthesized by the neurons and are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.
  • In the synaptic region, the plasma membrane of the presynaptic cell is specialized for vesicle exocytosis; synaptic vesicles, which contain a neurotransmitter, are clustered in these regions. The opposing membrane of the postsynaptic cell (in this case, a neuron) contains receptors for the neurotransmitter.

 

 

On electron microscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A . Mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies of 0.5-2.0 micron long on an electron microscope, consisting of an outer and an inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B. Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph represents presynaptic secretory vesicles, essential for neurotransmitter storage and release during synaptic transmission, highlighting their role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior gluteal artery

 

  • Origin: The inferior gluteal artery is typically a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually below the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles (mainly gluteus maximus), and also gives off branches that participate in anastomoses around the hip joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliolumbar Artery

 

  • Origin: This arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It ascends posteriorly to supply the iliacus muscle, the iliac bone, and the lumbosacral region. Its branches also participate in anastomoses with the lumbar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral Sacral Artery

 

  • Origin: This too arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: Generally, there are two lateral sacral arteries (superior and inferior) that descend to supply the sacrum and coccyx. They anastomose with the median sacral artery and with each other. Some branches of the lateral sacral arteries also supply the meninges of the sacral part of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Superior Gluteal Artery

 

  • Origin: This artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually above the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles and also contributes to the anastomotic network around the hip joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

 

  1. Vaginal artery (in females)
  2. Uterine artery (in females)
  3. Inferior vesical artery (in males) or vaginal artery (in females): supplies the urinary bladder and reproductive organs.
  4. Middle rectal artery: supplies the rectum and anal canal.
  5. Internal pudendal artery: supplies the perineum, external genitalia, and the lower anal canal.
  6. Obturator artery: supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, external genitalia, and the hip joint.
  7. Inferior gluteal artery: supplies the muscles of the gluteal region.
  8. Superior vesical artery: supplies the urinary bladder and the vas deferens.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B

 

The coracoid process is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa and is marked on the scapula as B. The coracoid process's tip is located approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). As a result, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include

 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament
  • Pectoralis minor
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius.

 

Option C. The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint.

 

Option D. The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process is a palpable landmark in the infraclavicular fossa, important for clinical examination and as a reference point for various shoulder procedures. Its recognition is crucial in the assessment of shoulder pathologies and for orientation during surgical approaches to the shoulder.

questions.text: A patient has come to the clinic. Identify the movement being examined in the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction

 

The image provided depicts a clinical examination known as the Trendelenburg test. This test is used to assess the strength and function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. These muscles, innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, stabilize the pelvis during walking by keeping the pelvis level when one leg is lifted off the ground.

 

 

In a normal Trendelenburg test, when the patient stands on one leg, the gluteus medius and minimus on the standing leg contract to elevate the pelvis on the opposite side, maintaining balance. If the superior gluteal nerve is damaged or the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Adduction refers to the movement of a limb toward the midline of the body. This is not the movement being assessed in the Trendelenburg test.

 

Option B. Extension: Extension is the straightening movement that increases the angle between body parts, such as straightening the leg at the hip joint. The Trendelenburg test does not assess extension.

 

Option C. Flexion: Flexion refers to bending a joint, decreasing the angle between body parts. The Trendelenburg test is not assessing flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of these muscles, often due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: Structures passing between marked points A and B? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stylopharyngeus

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking.

 

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing thorugh them

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus: This muscle runs from the soft palate to the pharynx, but it does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. Instead, it is involved in forming the palatopharyngeal arch.

 

Option C. Stylohyoid: This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts onto the hyoid bone. It is involved in elevating the hyoid bone during swallowing but does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Option D. Mylohyoid: This muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is involved in elevating the floor of the mouth during swallowing. It does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors, and it is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked by red arrow? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior oblique

 

The superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure highlighted in the figure. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

 

  • ﻿﻿Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • ﻿﻿Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure indicated by the red arrow in the image. This muscle helps in elevating the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus: Also supplied by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye towards the nose.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the LPS is essential for elevating the upper eyelid, enabling the opening of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the maneuver in image below. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pringle's maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a surgical procedure known as Pringle's maneuver, which involves inserting a finger from the greater sac to the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow). The epiploic foramen is the communication between the greater and lesser sacs, and its boundaries are of great importance.

During hepatobiliary surgery, there is a risk of rupturing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) located along the free margin of the lesser omentum. To prevent leakage from these structures, the surgeon can either clamp them along the free margin or insert a finger behind the lesser omentum and place the thumb above it, compressing the VAD between the finger and thumb. This surgical procedure is known as Pringle's maneuver.

 

 

The maneuver involves inserting the finger in front of the stomach (greater sac) and passing it behind the stomach (lesser sac) through the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mattox maneuver: Incorrect. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins during liver trauma. It involves a thoracoabdominal approach and manual compression of the bleeding site.

 

Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver: Incorrect. The Cattell-Braash maneuver is a surgical technique used to expose the retroperitoneal structures, such as the aorta, inferior vena cava, and kidneys, by mobilizing the colon and small bowel to the right side of the abdomen.

 

Option D. Liver hanging maneuver: Incorrect. The liver hanging maneuver is a technique used during liver resection to facilitate the transection of the liver parenchyma. It involves passing a tape or a catheter between the liver and the inferior vena cava to provide traction and guidance during the resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pringle's maneuver is a surgical procedure used to control bleeding during hepatobiliary surgery by compressing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) along the free margin of the lesser omentum through the epiploic foramen.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - Lamina propria 

 

Is an incorrect match because the structure labelled 4 shows the basement membrane rather than the lamina propria.

 

The image shows irregular cells attached to the basement membrane and is of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked as 4 in the image). It appears to have multiple layers. There is, however, only one layer of cells. The multi-layered appearance is caused by the nuclei of epithelial cells (shown as 3 in the image) being located at different levels.1`

 

The epithelium shows hair-like projections called cilia (marked as 1 in the image) and goblet cells (marked as 2 in the image). Goblet cells secrete mucous which helps to trap dust entering the passages. The cilia are capable of movement and help in the clearance of mucous

 

Example include epithelium lining the trachea and in large bronchi.

 

Other Options:

 

1- Cilia: These are the hair-like projections visible at the top of the epithelial cells, which help in moving mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory passages.

 

2- Goblet cells: These cells are interspersed between the epithelial cells and are responsible for producing mucus. They appear as clear, expanded cells at the level marked "2."

 

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell: The nuclei shown here are located at different heights within the cells, giving the epithelium a pseudostratified appearance.

 

4- Basement membrane: This layer supports the epithelium and is incorrectly labeled as the lamina propria in the options. It is a thin, fibrous structure evident just below the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure in the image are

 

1- Cilia

2- Goblet cell

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell

4- Basement membrane

questions.text: What is the condition shown in the image below? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rupture of biceps tendon

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a patient with a prominent bulge in the upper arm area, which is a classic sign of a proximal biceps tendon rupture. In a normal situation, the biceps muscle appears smooth and uniform. However, when the proximal biceps tendon ruptures, the biceps muscle belly becomes more prominent, creating a characteristic bulge.

 

This bulging appearance of the biceps muscle is known as the "Popeye sign" due to its resemblance to the exaggerated muscular appearance of the famous cartoon character Popeye the Sailor Man. In the American cartoon, Popeye would gain superhuman strength in his arms after eating spinach, which was portrayed as a rich source of iron.

 

Tendon ruptures are relatively common, with the four most frequently affected tendons being:

 

  1. Quadriceps tendon (Q)
  2. Achilles tendon (A)
  3. Rotator cuff tendons, particularly the supraspinatus (R)
  4. Biceps tendon (B)

 

These four tendons can be remembered using the mnemonic "QARB".

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaft of humerus fracture: Incorrect. A fracture of the humeral shaft would not cause the characteristic bulging appearance of the biceps muscle as seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rupture of triceps tendon: Incorrect. A triceps tendon rupture would cause weakness in elbow extension and a defect near the olecranon process, not a bulge in the biceps region.

 

Option D. Supracondylar fracture: Incorrect. A supracondylar fracture is a fracture of the distal humerus, above the elbow joint. It would not cause the biceps muscle to bulge in the manner shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Popeye sign" is a classic clinical sign of a proximal biceps tendon rupture, characterized by a prominent bulge in the biceps muscle belly.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Internal capsule

 

Explanation:

 

Above marked structure is internal capsule.

 

The internal capsule is a critical white matter structure in the brain. It is located deep within the cerebral hemispheres and separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus. The internal capsule contains axon tracts that serve as major pathways for communication between different parts of the brain, including the cortex, thalamus, and various subcortical nuclei.

 

The internal capsule is often subdivided into three parts: the anterior limb, genu (knee), and posterior limb. Each limb contains different types of nerve fibers that transmit motor, sensory, and other information between the cerebral cortex and other brain regions.

 

The internal capsule consists of several parts and is V-shaped when cut horizontally, in a transverse plane.

 

  • the bend in the V is called the genu
  • the anterior limb or crus anterius is the part in front of the genu, between the head of the caudate nucleus and the lenticular nucleus
  • the posterior limb or crus posterius is the part behind the genu, between the thalamus and lenticular nucleus
  • the retrolenticular portion is caudal to the lenticular nucleus and carries the optic radiation (from medial part of lateral geniculate nucleus) also known as the geniculocalcarine tract. The fiber from lateral part of lateral geniculate nucleus is carried through the retrolenticular portion.
  • the sublenticular portion is beneath the lenticular nucleus and are tracts involved in the auditory pathway from the medial geniculate nucleus to the primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42)

 

Lesions or damage to the internal capsule can result in various neurological deficits, including motor and sensory impairments.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. External Capsule: The external capsule is another white matter structure located in the brain, but it is less well-known than the internal capsule. It is located lateral to the putamen and globus pallidus and is considered part of the deep gray matter of the basal ganglia. The exact function and significance of the external capsule are still a subject of ongoing research, and its role in brain function is not as well-defined as that of the internal capsule.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe: The caudate lobe, also known as the caudate nucleus, is a part of the basal ganglia. It is a C-shaped structure located within each cerebral hemisphere. The caudate nucleus is involved in various functions, including motor control, cognition, and emotional processing. It is interconnected with other basal ganglia nuclei and plays a role in regulating movement. Lesions or dysfunction in the caudate nucleus can lead to movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease or Huntington's disease.

 

Option D. Globus Pallidus: The globus pallidus is another component of the basal ganglia. It is divided into two segments: the external segment (GPe) and the internal segment (GPi). The globus pallidus is involved in motor control and plays a role in modulating motor signals sent from the cortex to the thalamus. Dysfunctions of the globus pallidus can result in movement disorders, including dystonia and Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule's strategic location and structure facilitate critical communication pathways in the brain, making its integrity vital for normal motor and sensory functions. Damage to this area can lead to severe neurological deficits.

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb, is due to the involvement of the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN). This is a branch of the median nerve. It runs down the forearm along with the anterior interosseous artery.

 

It supplies the deep muscles of the anterior (flexor) compartment of the forearm. Specifically, it provides innervation to the flexor pollicis longus (which flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb), the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus. Injury to this nerve can lead to the inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, leading to the characteristic "pinch sign" or "OK sign" presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the ulnar nerve after it passes the flexor retinaculum in the wrist. The deep branch is mainly motor in function.

 

  • This nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles (muscles of the little finger), the ulnar two lumbricals, all the interossei (both palmar and dorsal), and adductor pollicis. It does not have any role in the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Option B. Median Nerve: This nerve originates from both the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus. It travels down the arm and forearm and goes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist.

 

  • It supplies most of the flexors in the forearm and several muscles in the hand, including the thenar muscles (muscles of the thumb). But the flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb is more specifically due to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, not the main trunk of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Posterior Interosseous Nerve: It is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve. It travels in the forearm between the superficial and deep layers of muscles.

 

  • This nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. It's not involved in flexion movements and hence, not responsible for the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexion of thumb occurs at 2 joints:

 

  1. IP joint: Flexor pollicis longs (FPL) supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve, C7 and C8).
  2. MCP joint: Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB supplied by the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Most commonly injured nerve in SCH fracture: AIN > Median > Radial > Ulnar (AMRU)

 

  • Deep branch of ulnar nerve → ulnar claw hand
  • Posterior interosseous nerve → innervates the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. Weakness or paralysis of these muscles can cause difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (4, 9, 12, 1) structures:

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)
  2. Mitral valve
  3. Tricuspid valve
  4. Papillary muscles
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a-1, b-4, c-9, D-12

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cut and reflected section of the heart.

 

The ventricles can be identified based upon the wall thickness - Left ventricle has thicker walls.

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (marked as 1): This structure represents the exit point for blood traveling to the lungs for oxygenation.
  2. Mitral valve (marked as 4): Located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, the mitral valve regulates blood flow within the heart.
  3. Tricuspid valve (marked as 9): This valve, situated between the right atrium and right ventricle, prevents backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria.
  4. Papillary muscles (marked as 12): These muscles are attached to the ventricular walls and play a critical role in the function of the mitral and tricuspid valves via tendon-like chords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match is:

 

1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)

2. Left atrium

3. Pulmonary veins (light red)

4. Mitral valve

5. Aorta (red).

6. Superior vena cava (blue)

7. Aortic semi lunar valve

8. Right atrium

9. Tricuspid valve

10. Right ventricle

11. Inferior vena cave (blue)

12. Papillary muscles

13. Left ventricle

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior cerebellar

 

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.

 

  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.

 

  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C. Internal carotid artery (ICA): It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery). Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of cerebellum:

 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon.

 

The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibres of internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A- Thoracolumbar fascia - This fascia covers the deep muscles of the back and abdomen at the thoracic and lumbar regions.

 

Option B. B- Fibers of transverse abdominis

 

Option D. D- Inguinal ligament - A band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine, forming the lower border of the abdomen and serving as a landmark in hernia repairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transversus Abdominis muscle

 

Origin: Internal surface of 7th -12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.

 

Insertion: Linea Alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.
